Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2008 05:16PM nixieschaos wrote: Hezzy...I believe in my heart that it is your way of dealing with this that is bringing you the successes. We are so alike! i have mets to the bone as well. mine was in the hip, femur, rib, sternum, I forget where else. I was diagnosed last Oct 4.  Just like you, I went to work (missed one day), came home and cooked for my family, cleaned house, did the shopping... My cancer didn't consume me. It surfaced when I lost my hair, and would be a massive inconvenience  for about nine days after my AC/zometa coctail hour. I didn't get on the phone, alert the media about my cancer. i was not shy about telling people either, because I felt that the more people sending good vibes & prayers my way the better.   As my friends learned about my cancer, they called me sobbing, and i would always have a funny story about something I did because of my chemo brain...I think when dealing with people like us, the public at large has no idea how to handle us...it is far easier to comfort someone who is falling apart. What I did, and DO is force people to follow my lead...I refused to entertain any notion of my being sick. It does take a persistent effort to get people to respond the way we need, but we have to be patient and didigent in what we expect and 'train' those we come into contact with to behave the way we need them to in order to save our sanity !  My most recent cat scan and bone scan are clear with the exception of a small leision on my scapula...could be a bone cyst. I think the outcome would have been as the original diagnosing doc predicted if I hadn't taken things as I did. 20% survival rate???!!!!! Bull &%**. Let them say you are in denial...What EVER!  I think we need to see more stage IV women who are successfully battling this disease. Early detection is best, I would love to have been a member of that club. But  I wasn't and I will win... You will too...
Posts.Title: people keep asking hezzy nixieschaos

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2008 05:29PM nixieschaos wrote: River... one out of 13 women made it!!!! Well, i am here to say we are going to blow their statistic... yeah, i get tired of being told i am an inspiration...BUT I love it when someone is SPECIFIC about how my dealing with thIS situation has helped them. You know, it's so wierd...i have been struggling all of my life with the who Am I question. Somehow always unsettled. I was just relaxing the other day and had this warmth rush over me. i realized that i am really at peace with who i am. I gave a talk last night to caregivers, and in the material I was presenting, the caregivers were told to give themselves credit for what they do every day. I feel like, over the past year, i have accomplished something really great. Really. I feel like when i get through this, i can accomplish anything. it is amazing reading all of these posts. They should bottle us up and put us into a chemo bag...What a good dose of cancer woop ass that would be!
Posts.Title: people keep asking hezzy nixieschaos

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2008 01:31PM nixieschaos wrote: fllorik, I guess the warrior in me means that I refuse to live with cancer...it moved into MY house, and I want it OUT, and fight it every step until I get my way! The warrior in me refuses to accept what the doctors tell me, and what the drug companies tell me..I question EVERYTHING, accept nothing. Even the positives, Especially the positives, I question.  The warrior in me is taking an active role in my healing...I seek out alternatives to the drugs every day, I search for new foods that can prevent or kill the cancer inside me...The warrior in me made it possible for me to miss ONE day of work in a year during the adrimycin/cytoxin/Zometa. The warrior in me is kicking the crap out of this and will continue to do so forever, if I have to. I get told how wonderful I look...Well, I better!! I just spent ALOT of money on this new wig, thank you very much!!!!! I just thank GOD for the wigs...AND eyebrow pencil!!!!! What a frightening sight...me without hair and EYEBROWS.  Definetly not for the faint of heart!  This is where we need to retrain the thinking out there. i think people are expecting to see the typical 'sickley' person...We should all merge our best pics into one and send it to the media...all of us with our middle fingers flying proudly, saluting this stupid disease!
Posts.Title: people keep asking hezzy nixieschaos

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2009 11:47PM nixieschaos wrote: Hey, how do you feel about alternative (rather inexpensive) alt supplements?There is so much pressure to take the traditional road, but I hear so much successes with alternative treatments. I did an alt along with my chemo. I am stageIV and my only issue right now is the bone mets, which I am going to handle with nutrition and getting my Ph in line. Just because you have chosen to forgoe the traditional methods, doesn't mean the end sweetie. I will be happy to tell you what I am doing...The most terrible awful thing that could haopen is that you feel pretty darn good for a while??? Please contact me by email and I will tell you the route I took.

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2008 08:00AM nixieschaos wrote: It's as realistic to work during chemo as she believes it to be. I just finished 7 months of chemo and never missed a day. Don't tell her she can't do it. Help her get her body strong. She will need it if she is going to look after a 2 and 4 year old! She will need support for her immune system. Look at the Amazon Protocol by Nutranomics. I bagan taking it before I began treatments and I swear by it. The site is nutranomics.com. Seriously...I was told I was nothing short of a miracle just last week. I think Amazon Protocol, diet and attitude made all the difference for me.

Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2008 06:59PM nixieschaos wrote: Where are you? (What State?) I am SO very fortunate to have a family friend who is one of the leading breast cancer guys in the country. I will be speaking to him tomorrow. I can ask if you'd like?? This doc is two hours away, so I started with a doc in my area. She set my treatment plan, I saw Charlie and he revised her plan. It worked, so I don't care if she was offended.You are NOT a whiner!!! I believe it is best in our situation to question EVERYTHING ... ACCEPT NOTHING. And if someone gets butthurt over you wanting a second, third or TENTH opinion...well, too bad.  A true professional will appreciate the opportunity to learn from other professionals.   I never had an MRI. I know that the mother of all...the PET scan shows some false positives. Your best bet is to get with someone who you feel will guide you in the right direction.
Posts.Title: scared and worried lissa71 nixieschaos

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 01:41AM - edited Feb 20, 2008 01:48AM by nixieschaos Oh Barbara, How are you feeling? Just a couple of weeks ago, I had that respiratory flu (rampant in my area). I fought off what I thought was a mild cold for about a week, went for my last treatment of my first round of Chemo, and two days later, I was sick as a dog. I did NOT take anything... not over the counter, advil...nothing. I wanted to see how my body would fight it on it's own. My husband got it and I recovered before he did. My point is that I am taking things to strengthen my immune system. I don't listen to the docs about what to feed my body. I don't think they have a clue!!! I am so glad that you are taking matters back into your own hands...Dairy? Animal protein??? They told you to eat that??? CHEESE????? Wow. I was feeling like crap until I got cancer...hehe. I started eating like you did before your cancer and I feel better than ever....go figure. ( Ok, so I don't feel better than ever ALL the time... I feel like I have morning sickness , all day for about a week after chemo. Bleh) I went out of town and had to put off my chemo for a week. I felt so good I tried to put if off for another DAY. They wouldn't let me...Now they call me the day before to make sure I don't go AWOL...it's tempting!) Really, I do hope you are feeling better. I'll say a little prayer for you tonight. EAT FOR YOUR LIFE!!!  We are warriors and this disease has invaded OUR world.This life is ours and they can't have it!
Posts.Title: Why am I not upset? Barbara1 Mary-Lou

Posts.Title: IV for chemo - is hand vein ok? LorenaB wishiwere

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2009 02:38AM nixieschaos wrote: Wow, You are so not going to like this, but your LIFE depends on pulling your self out of this. How about planning the trip to have a BLAST with your girls, because you all deserve to get away and have fun??? You will all have your great memories, but for a different reason! Changing your mindset requires a great deal of thought on your part...you need to practice being positive every second of every day. Have you been doing anything else to heal other than chemo? It's amazing how taking some control over your health will help your attitude. I have read posts where everyone is sick of hearing others say "stay positive" . I think most people say that because they don't know what else to say, but our mind is an amazing thing, and our body will do what our mind tells it to do. My mind is , well, just odd...I am stage IV mets to the bone. I have honestly never had a moment that I have doubted that I would be healed. That positive focus and taking control of my health  have contributed to my successes over the last year. And guess what? I bet a million dollars that this post will be skipped over... I am writing my own story. You need to do the same. Once again, your life depends on it. If you want to hear what I have been doing in detail send me an email. Let's beat this BITCH called cancer...
Posts.Title: Emotional Yo Yo.... AimeeFaye barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2008 03:09PM - edited Jun 2, 2008 03:10PM by nixieschaos C, I talked with our nurse. She didn't see any issue with the surgery other than the fact that, as I am sure you know, you will need to closley monitor her because of her inability to follow instructions. Her dementia may increase, temporarily, just due to the surgery, and being thrown out of her routine so just know that, as I have seen many times, she may try to remove her bandages, because she won't remember what they are for. You are right, she is in the most difficult stage. As she progresses, you will find it easier, because she will not be as aware of her memory loss. Through the Alzheimer's Association, there is a book called "Coach Broyle's Playbook for Caregivers". He was a coach for the Arkansas Razorbacks, whose wife was diagnosed. He was her caregiver. This book is wonderful. It is literally what it's called, a playbook. He even made up a pocket size "what to do when this happens" kind of thing. There is also a book called "Learning to Speak Alzheimer's" It is amazing. I highly recommend it.   Good luck to you, and I wish your mom well through her surgery and recovery.
Posts.Title: Alzhiemer's and breast cancer cgraham cgraham

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2008 03:21PM - edited Oct 20, 2008 03:25PM by nixieschaos the delay in your results is because your doc OFFENDED someone??? I was diagnosed 1 year ago. I went through all of the diagnostic tests...CAT scan, bone scan, PET scan, etc... and called the radiologist after every one and checked on the progress of the results and had them give me a CD. They wouldn't give me the CD until my doctor had the results, but my calls helped move the process along...The squeaky wheel...you know.  I also got my own copies of my mamograms and ultrasounds. If I were you, I would do the same.   To ease your mind, maybe you should get another opinion (the reason for getting the CDs). (And a second opinion is a good idea anyway). I also would not accept the appt date of 12/30. That is ridiculous. is that because the surgeon is booked until 12/30? Consider calling daily, or weekly to see if there is a cancellation, or seek out another doctor who can see you sooner. And get your mind around WHATEVER you find out. Decide NOW that you can handle whatever comes your way. I bet everything is going to be fine. Heck, i was diagnosed stage IV a year ago...i am clear today (But don't think i didn't get three opinions before saying THAT out loud!!!)
Posts.Title: scared and worried lissa71 nixieschaos

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2008 11:23AM nixieschaos wrote: Hey Barbara, I am 5 months into this. I just said, "wow" over and over when I was diagnosed with Stage 4 inflamatory ductal carcenoma, mets to the bone. I cry from time to time, but not about what has happened to me, but out of frustration that I don't feel fantastic for a week out of the month. I DON'T DOUBT FOR A SECOND THAT I WILL BEAT THIS THING. It is what it is. I decided I could cry and ask why, or just take it as it comes and deal with it one step at a time. I am comforting those who call me sobbing when they hear the news, and I get them laughing. I know I have a battle and have armed myself mentally and physically to meet any challenge that comes my way. I, too have faith in God. As long as I use the tools that he gave me, the foods that he put on this earth to nourish us, and keep him in my heart, I will win. You will win. It's overwhelming, all of the information. Know yourself well enough to determine what you can handle as far as what you take in, and don't allow your mind to be poisoned by negativity. Hard to imagine THAT ONE when the very nature of this is very negative. But you are going to choose how this plays out. Make your choice and run with it. We are warriors and this disease has invaded OUR world. That's what I live by. I wish you well. Be strong and kick this thing in it's A_ _!

Posts.Title: IV for chemo - is hand vein ok? LorenaB wishiwere

Posts.Content: May 30, 2008 02:53AM nixieschaos wrote: Oh, I am so sorry that you are faced with this. How well do her doctors understand Alzheimer's Disease? Unfortunately, most don't. There is so much to consider. I have worked with Alzheimer's for almost 6 years. How old is your mother?  What stage Alzeimer's is she? What stage is her BC? These things are factors, among others. I work in an Alzheimer's specialty Community. I am going to bring this to my nurse tomorrow (Friday). She is amazing, and worked in a skilled setting for years before coming to us. I will post her thoughts tomorrow morning. Wow, how difficult. The thing is, that folks with Alzheimer's disease live anywhere from 2 - 20 years after diagnosis. You may be on the right track in your thought process. How aware is she? What is her orientation to time and place? Are you caring for her in her home or does she live in a community? Having done this for 6 years, I have met many people with Cancer and Alz. For the most part, they don't remember that they have Cancer. Many times, it is complications from the Alz that affects them before the cancer does.  If she has the surgery, you are right. The post surgery and the healing process will be more challenging on many levels, due to her inability to comprehend or retain what is going on. The trauma of this kind of surgery could accelerate the progression of her disease. Please give me more info. I can get you the information you need so you can make a good sound decision.

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2008 02:43AM - edited Jun 5, 2008 02:45AM by nixieschaos Oh C, I know. It is so hard. In my recent support group meeting, A woman had a very interesting thought about this disease and how families can deal with the loss of the person we know, to the diaease. Her husband has Alz. He is a veteran, was born in sweden, etc...These things obviously before she knew him. She learned about the war he fought in, learned about Swedish tradition, which he is remembering vividly now and some other things. She said she has lost the relationship she knows, but is now focusing on building a new relationship, based on his long term memories. She is helping him by understanding where he is in the disease process, keeping him engaged, because she is able to have a conversation with him about what he is remembering at the time. It is helping her, because she learns something new about him, and she doesn't feel so helpless.
Posts.Title: Alzhiemer's and breast cancer cgraham cgraham

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2009 02:02AM nixieschaos wrote: Hey, I feel pretty safe in saying that any true professional simply wouldn't offer any type of advice without knowing all of the specifics related to your particular situation. I live in a small town in California, about 140 miles from Los Angeles. I was diagnosed stage IV infiltrating Ductal Carcenoma mets to the bone. Also Her2+. With this type, very agressive, I got advise from EVERYBODY to get the heck out of town and seek out an onc in Los Angeles, City of Hope...(Anywhere but here type of thing). I hit walls everywhere I turned, then my sister called me to tell me that a very good friend of her in-law's is one of the leading Oncologists in the country... With their referral, I saw him within 2 days. He had all of my scans and reports...He said he would be happy to do chemo in his office, but that the drive may be too much, as he was recommending a very agressive treatment plan. I opted to do the chemo locally and Dr. Wiseman would act as a consultant of sorts, giving his opinions to my local oncologist and seeing me every 4 mionths or so to be sure we were staying on track. It is working out beautifully. What's going on with you? Let me know...I may have some thoughts to share, but I am curious about you first. Oh, by the way...I am being told I am like a miracle child...I would love to share more, but telling my story is exhausting. There is so much. I want to be sure you are up for it before I take the time. It's worth it, I promise, but many folks resist what I tell them and then I am frusterated. So let me know what's going on and if you are the open minded type! I do wish you well!!! Steph
Posts.Title: I'm Looking for an Oncology Consultant Toronto111 mason204

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2008 08:03PM nixieschaos wrote: When i shaved my head (when the first clump came out in my hand) it was a shock. I had anticipated it, of course, and had a plan, but I was not prepared for how sudden it was...We went to a local wig shop and bought a wig. it was long, wavy and brown. (That was all they had!!!!) I was medium length and blonde. I wore it to church that night, with my hair tucked under it. Every time I passed a window, I was startled! My husband & I  laughed that some friend would walk up to him and slap his face and accuse him of cheating on me. The next day, we had a shave mom's head party. Too funny. At the first swipe, I was committed. I bought tape. Needs to happen. Just imagine...a sudden burst of wind and the darn thing is in the trees!!! You need to be able to take your hair off. it does get hot, at times but it's not that bad...REALLY. There is a site...wilshire wigs.com that you might look at. If you go to a wig salon, you will pay twice, maybe three times what you will pay wilshire wigs. if you have a wig shop, go in NOW to get your mind wrapped around what you are going to do. A decent synthetic wig will run you around $170.00, but you could pay hundreds. You'll pay around 80 at wilshire, for the salon's 170.00 wig. just get the brand and style name. Set you mind to have fun with this. It is what it is, so just make the best of what you are dealt. i have red, blonde, brown, long, short...depends on my mood and what i am wearing. I know some just opt for the scarves and choose the natural. I took this as an opportunity to be anyone i wanted to be whenever i wanted to be...it. My hair started to grow back in patches. i kept my head shaved until it all started coming in. now my hair is thick as heck. it's only about an inch long, but it is coming in very well.
